review.title: Propagating Conjunctions of AllDifferent Constraints
review.abstract: We study propagation algorithms for the conjunction of two AllDifferent constraints. Solutions of an AllDifferent constraint can be seen as perfect matchings on the variable/value bipartite graph. Therefore, we investigate the problem of finding simultaneous bipartite matchings. We present an extension of the famous Hall theorem which characterizes when simultaneous bipartite matchings exists. Unfortunately, finding such matchings is NP-hard in general. However, we prove a surprising result that finding a simultaneous matching on a convex bipartite graph takes just polynomial time. Based on this theoretical result, we provide the first polynomial time bound consistency algorithm for the conjunction of two AllDifferent constraints. We identify a pathological problem on which this propagator is exponentially faster compared to existing propagators. Our experiments show that this new propagator can offer significant benefits over existing methods.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: They capture patterns that often occur in practice (e.g., "These courses must take place at different times"), and associate rapid propagation algorithms with any global constraint to think about possible solutions (e.g., "These four courses have only three time windows between them, by a drawer argument, the problem is unfeasible.") One of the oldest and most useful global constraints is the compulsion to reason (Laurie re 1978), which suggests that one set of variables includes all other values. Many different algorithms have been proposed for the propagation of compulsion (Leconte 1996; Puget 1998).

sections.heading: Experimental results
sections.text: To evaluate the performance of our decomposition, we conducted an experiment on random problems. We used Ilog 6.2 on an Intel Xeon 4 CPU, 2.0 GHz, 4GB RAM. We compared the performance of DC, BC (LopezOrtiz et al. 2003) propagators and our decomposition into constraints (3) - (12) for the OVERLAPPINGALLDIFF constraint (OBC). We used randomly generated problems with three global constraints: ALLDIFFERENT (X-W), ALLDIFFERENT (Y-W) and ALLDIFFERENT (Z-W), as well as a linear number of binary order relationships between variables in X, Y and Z. We used a random variable order and executed each instance with 50 different seeds. As shown in Table 1, our decomposition significantly reduces the search space and solves more cases overall.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: This generalization suggests a polynomial time algorithm to find a concurrent agreement in a convex bilateral graph. We have applied this to a problem in constraint programming of propagating conjunctions of ALLDIFFERENT constraints. Initial experimental results suggest that thinking about such conjunctions can significantly reduce the size of the search space studied. There are several possibilities for future research. For example, the algorithmic techniques proposed in (Puget 1998) and (LopezOrtiz et al. 2003) can be generalized to simultaneous bilateral linkages, resulting in more efficient multipliers. Furthermore, matchings are used to propagate other constraints such as NVALUE (Bessiere et al 2006) when it is otherwise possible to apply similar insights to develop multipliers for conjunctions of other global constraints, or to improve existing multiplication repositories for specific cases, such as 2008.
